lexUnit.name: must.v
lexUnit.definition: FN: be strongly required in order to avoid negative consequences, social or otherwise

sentence.text: ` We really must find out when Karl is coming back , " Frau Nordern went on .
When at last Tamar and Stephen decided that they really must leave , Victoria pleaded for them to stay a little longer .
` I really must be going to Matey , Dr Neil .
She really must put Maria Luisa and Steve and Fernando out of her mind and concentrate on what she was here on the island of Majorca for -- to work .
This exists simply because he must necessarily reveal aspects of a closed and somewhat secretive society to the outside if he is to pursue any ethnography at all .
It is made clear that this does not simply mean that each school must offer such a curriculum ; each individual pupil must take it up .
Put very simply , in order to know anything we must assume certain things in faith .
Throughout the speech you must speak loudly , aiming to be heard by the person at the far end of the room .
We must do still more , and we shall .
I 'll come home when I can , but I must go to London .
I must go to England to do the work and I want to marry Elizabeth when I return . "
Flora must get herself a job , he said , then she would not have to go to India .
They must take a realistic view and look objectively when deciding which movements will best describe individuality .
Media and social pressures must take some of the blame for the increase in debt .
` You must take his place , " said their father to Paul .
It believes that theological colleges and courses must take a new look at the quantity and quality of the preparation given to ordinands for their responsibilities in leading public worship .
If such people are not genuine asylum seekers we must take action to protect the rest of the community , including the ethnic minorities , from them .
Each local authority must compile a register containing the names and addresses of those within the area who are liable to pay the tax and the dates from which they become , or cease to be , liable .
I must find Maggie .
You must stand guard over him at all times . "
Finally , the citizen must , if true to his quality , be possessed of some civic virtue .
He must , if necessary ( and many children manage this ) , become bilingual , able to switch as the occasion demands between what may be virtually or actually two languages .
Teachers must always realise that the ` obvious purpose of school is to fit children to the society in which they will grow up " .
